On 29th Feb. the prisoner came, asked for half a pint of porter, and paid, me with a 4d.-piece—I examined it, found it was bad, gave it him back, and he threw it over the counter back again—a policeman came, I marked the 4d., and gave it to him—this is it (produced).
Prisoner. Q. Did I offer you two 4d.-pieces? A. the constable took the other one out of your hand—you were going to give it to me, and the policeman took it away from you.

JAMES BERRY (policeman, M 163). I went to Holt's house, and saw the prisoner there—Holt gave me a bad 4d.-piece, which she said the prisoner had offered her—as I was speaking to her the prisoner said, "Let us have a drop of gin," and I saw him take a 4d.-piece from his mouth—I caught hold of his hand and took this 4d.-piece (produced) from it—sergeant Watkins came in, and I assisted him in taking this third 4d.-piece from the prisoner's mouth—I took the prisoner to the station, and there found another 4d.-piece (produced) on him, and 3d. in halfpence.
THOMAS WATKINS (policeman, M 19). I went to the public-house, saw the prisoner there, and took this 4d.-piece (produced) from his mouth.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These four 4d.-pieces are all bad, and three of them are from the same mould.
Prisoner. I tool these 4d.-pieces in change.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Six Month.

471.
WILLIAM WALSHAM LEGGETT was again indicted (see page 560), and
DAVID RHODES
. for stealing 1 coat, value 1l.; the goods of
James Glode Stapleton; and 1 umbrella, 2s.; the goods of
Rebecca Glode Sta
pleton.—2nd COUNT, receiving the same, knowing them to have been stolen.

RHODES pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined four Month.

JAMES GLODE STAPLETON . I live at Clapham-rise. On 16th March, about a quarter past 6, I hung up my coat in the hall—shortly after that a young man called, and I afterwards missed it—this is it (produced)—this umbrella (produced) is my sister's, Rebecca Glode Stapleton—it was in the hall before it was lost—I had not seen it there myself—Ann Duffy, who is in our service, is Rhodes's aunt.
JOHN LARTER (policeman, L 166). Rhodes gave himself into my custody at the Court.

GEORGE BARTMAN . I am assistant to Mr. Tarrant, a pawnbroker. I pro
duce the coat—it was pledged for 7s., by Leggett, in the name of William Jones, on 17th March.
ANN DUFFY . The prisoner Rhodes is my nephew.
JAMES PAGETT . I am a hairdresser, at Clerkenwell. This umbrella was sold to me by Leggett.
AMELIA BURR . I am in Mr. Stapleton's service. I recollect Rhodes coming on 16th March, about 5 minutes past 7 o'clock; after that the coat was missed.
Leggett's Defence. I own to pawning the coat and selling the umbrella; I did not know they were stolen.

LEGGETT
GUILTY on Second Count. Aged 25.—
Confined Six Months.

472.
JOSEPH FOX and
HANNAH HERBERT
stealing 1 blanket, 1 pillow, and other articles, value 4s. 6d.; the goods of
Robert Robertson, let by him to be used by the said prisoners.

FRANCES ROBERTSON . I am the wife of Robert Robertson. We let lodg
ings; the prisoners came to lodge at our house as man and wife, on the Tuesday before 1st March—I do not live in the house—I went there on 1st March, found they were gone, and missed a counterpane, pillow, blanket, a set of Venetian blinds, two cups, two saucers, and a basin—I have seen them all since but the blinds, these are them (produced)—they are my husband's.

LEWIS BRAY (policeman, P 105). On 9th March I took the prisoners, at 14, Queen's-row, Walworth—they were using these cups and saucers for their tea—I found two duplicates relating to this property, and sixteen others, concealed in the wall inside the paper.

JAMES FANCHON . I live with Mr. Wharton, a pawnbroker. This pillow and quilt were pledged with me on 1st March, in the name of Smith, for 1s. 6d., and the blanket on 9th March for 1s., I believe by the female prisoner—the duplicates produced are what I gave for the articles.

MARY ANN COX . I am the wife of Robert Cox, and live at Mr. Robert
son's house. On 1st March, about 5 o'clock in the evening, I saw Fox go out with a parcel under his arm—a few minutes after that I saw Herbert go out with the baby, a small basket, and a bundle.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you ever go out with a bundle? A. Yes, many a time.

FOX—
NOT GUILTY .

HERBERT—
GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Two Months.

473.
JOSEPH FOX was again indicted
for stealing 2 sheets, and other articles, value 8s. 6d.; the goods of
William Rogers; upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

474.
JOSEPH FOX was again indicted
for stealing 1 blanket, and other articles, value 4s.; the goods of
Benjamin Sans, let by him, &c.; upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: The following Prisoners, upon whom the Judgment of the Court was respited at the time of Trial, have been sentenced as under:

Shean, Norah, alias
Ann Johnston 94 Confined six days.
Newman, Ann Harriet... 105 Confined four months.
Boulter, Thomas... 165 Judgment arrested and discharged.

Weir, Hannah, alias
Olivia Davidson 272 Transported for ten years.
Rushton, James William... 325 Confined two days.
Garnett, George Howson... 362 and 648 Still respited.
Gerber, Arnold... 464 Transported for ten years.
Wagner, William... 464 Transported for ten years.
Kessler, Philip... 464 Transported for ten years.
